contentrichtext.text: {{Orphan|date=December 2012}} '''Onegesius''' ([[Priscus]]: ''Όνηγήσιος'') was a noble of [[Huns|Hunnic]] or [[Scythian]] origin and one of the principal advisers of [[Attila the Hun]]. Onegesius was Western Roman. He was captured and [[Attila the Hun]] spared his life and brought him to the capital to join his court. Onegesius served Attila the Hun's as his architect. Attila ordered him to build a Roman bath in the Hun capital - [[Jászberény]]. Since the city was in the middle of the [[Great Hungarian Plan]] and that part of the country had no stones or trees, they had to transport the stones and timber from [[Pannonia]].<ref name="ReferenceA">Priscus at the court of Attila Translation by J.B. Bury (Priscus, fr. 8 in Fragmenta Historicorum Graecorum)</ref> When the bath was ready, Attila was so pleased, he appointed him as his bath master and main architect. Soon after, he married a noble [[Scythian]] woman. After this Attila made him his Minister and Warlord. <ref name="ReferenceA"/><ref>[[Patrick Howarth]], ''Attila: King of the Huns: The Man and the Myth'', Carroll & Graf, Oct. 10, 2001, ISBN 0-7867-0930-8, esp. pp. 27, 141.</ref> Also known as '''Hunigis''', '''Hunigisios''' or '''Hunigasius'''.{{citation needed|date=February 2007}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Onegesius | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = | DATE OF BIRTH = | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} [[Category:Huns]] {{Europe-mil-bio-stub}}
